commentBody:
Nice one!
Thanks, Kate.
Personal best yesterday. Near PB today. What's with these easy late week puzzles?

Sam says:

45D. Don‚Äôt fear the seeming brusqueness of the single letter [x]. It generally means one of two things as a clue: in uppercase, the Roman numeral for ten, or, in lowercase, the sign for multiplication ‚Äî as in TIMES.
_____

Not so, at least not recently.  In the last 10 appearances, dating back to 2020, a capital X as a clue has been clued to TEN only twice; the other eight times, its answer was CHI.

It has also been the clue for DELETE, CANCEL, MARK or ILLITERATE'S MARK, and some others, including DECEM.

The use of the lower-case x for TIMES is more reliable, but it has also clued UNKNOWN NTT (i.e. entity) and DELETE.
The puzzles aren't getting easier, I'm getting smarter.  Yes, that must be it.
I don‚Äôt think they are getting easier. We are getting smarter!

Fun clues and fresh entries made this breezy puzzle a joy. My biggest hiccup was having bravo instead of BRAVA, and not seeing the mistake right away because the crosses filled in sosses, and I failed to check.  I liked all the long acrosses, especially SWEATERWEATHER.

Much better than last week, but still seems a bit easy to me for a Friday.

A nice, moderately chewy puzzle that didn't take much time to complete.  Basically no filler.  A few things I didn't know.  Safely back to normal I hope.

The NYT has been messing with the web interface to games lately.  It's not good.  The music can play repeatedly when revisiting a solved puzzle, the fonts look off, there is sometimes but not reliably a new "you finished this" banner, and the "Admire" button no longer does anything.  It's pretty much a mess.

"Brava!" to Kate for the puzzle. 

But not a fan of the cluing of "Well done!" for [BRAVA] given that's Italian. And here where we speak English, "bravo" is the norm regardless of gender or number. 

I'll just file it away now that cluing could be for a word ending in A, E, I, or O (but not U or Y). 

Maybe Friday puzzles don't need foreign language markers? Bravi to all of those that knew.
Just wanna say that user != customer. Honestly, it‚Äôs probably more often than not that the user of a piece of software wasn‚Äôt the buyer of it (and the buyer is always the real customer).
54D has me stumped. Carry on? Carry what?

A lot of fun clues‚Äîmy favorite was the one for SNOWDAYS.

POLEDANCERS somehow didn‚Äôt fit for ones who grind at work, and BARBERSHOPQUARTET didn‚Äôt work for social activity with a vest (although LASERTAG was my second guess).

It was funny to see WIZENS as an entry in the same puzzle as ‚ÄúGets wise to?‚Äù

Still seeing what seems to be a lot of easier than usual clues for a Friday, but enough engaging clues and entries from a quality constructor that it still made for a satisfying solve.
Really enjoyed this. Average time but had to work for it. Loved SWEATER WEATHER and the clue for REVERSE ENGINEER. Thanks!

Given the fact that I had an almost 4-Hour drive . across Florida to get to Daytona tonight, I could say that I‚Äôm glad that it was an easy Friday puzzle. I‚Äôm not. Now I have to hope that Saturday is a good one. I may have to give up doing the puzzles entirely. They just aren‚Äôt as much fun if they‚Äôre this easy. It‚Äôs just getting worse.
I saw my doc the other day about a sensitive matter.  He had me sign an NDA and now I feel great!

Fun puzzle but I echo the comments from yesterday - late week puzzles have become far less challenging of late. I know NYT doesn't publish this data but GenAI estimates suggest the number of daily unique NYT crossword solvers has shot up from 150k to 2M in the last 15-20 years so I get the need to make the puzzles more 'mainstream'. While the focus on having fewer US-centric clues and making the Mon-Wed puzzles more accessible is great, will be nice to have early-mid 2010s difficulty levels at least for the end of week puzzles.

I really liked the long entries. My husband and I both do a lot REVERSE ENGINEERing, and our kids have picked up the habit. SWEATER WEATHER is definitely here and I love it! I do wish that the clueing was a little tougher, but that isn‚Äôt Kate‚Äôs fault. Thank you for kicking off the weekend, Kate.

It was great, but I did not like the SKU/KAREN/ELGIN group. I cannot guess the K and N over here. Elgin is not a guessable name.  Same for Sku. These were bad entries. Ruined the end for me as I had to google/reveal.

34 across was very nicely clued and some of the trivia -- Marne and the language Aztecs spoke -- was all right but there wasn't a lot of excitement here. And please let's stop verbing apes. The primates who tackle these puzzles shouldn't have to wade through boring often reused crosswordese like this. Let's ban the Oreo too.

Great puzzle.

But . . . SHOED?

commentBody: ...and the "late-week" gaslighting campaign continues...

I'm glad that so many found this one to be delightful, fun, whatever, but for me, the puzzles are starting to all look alike.  Not the clues, but the difficulty. I miss being really challenged by strong cluing and clever fills.  There were some in this puzzle, but the crosses drew their teeth, and the result was an easy puzzle.

Obviously, the responsibility of choosing the day a puzzle will run doesn't rest with the constructor, and Kate gave us a really nice puzzle, just not Friday tough.  So thank you, Kate, for a puzzle that was fun enough, just not mean enough.

commentBody:
dutchiris's and Jacqui J's indefatigably optimistic takes on the ever more dismal and desultory dulling of the late-week grids really have helped me realize that the setters cannot be blamed.

It is obviously the editors' job to pick more appropriate days or amp up the clue wattage.

And it cannot be, as some posters have suggested, that setters are simply not submitting difficult puzzles.

So, my thanks to Kate Hawkins and others whose puzzles I have insensitively maligned as too easy or inappropriately benign for late-week publication.

The fault, dear solver, is not in these stars, / But in those editors, that they are underlings.

I know.

Tortured the paraphrase.

Hopping in here with my two cents as a full-time contrarian (and part-time statistics nerd)‚Ä¶

I‚Äôd love to see xwordinfo data over the aggregate (as well as the standard deviation of solve times of Fridays, or any day really) because us humans have a hell of a time reckoning with recency bias (as well as another dozen or so biases) when evaluating the difficulty of crosswords as of late.

Anecdotes are great but overall I would to venture to say that a streak of easy-ish Fridays *has happened* in the past over the many decades of NYT and *will happen* again in the future.

Let‚Äôs cut the editors some slack and appreciate their creativity and hard work in tandem with the constructors!
BRAVA? If not for 57A it should be BRAVO given the clue.
I'm recovering from minor surgery and feeling fairly woolly-headed so I for one was very glad for this gentle Friday with some lively cluing :)

I store my sweaters next to my dairy products. Where there's a wool, there's a whey.

(Must be a curdigan sweater.)

BRAVA Kate!
Fun TIMES solving this puzzle!
We‚Äôre in AWE of your masterful puzzle making. 
Full steam AHEAD! CAN‚ÄôT STOP, won‚Äôt stop, we want MORE!

The NYT editing time is ruining the puzzles.

I have nothing against the constructor; this was a perfectly cromulent puzzle. However, I finished the combination of Friday and Thursday in the time that it took me to do Wednesday this week. Today's puzzle was half my Friday average; it belongs on a Wednesday.

As to this specific puzzle, it was fun with some delightful cling and cute answers. Nothing wrong with it at all.

I was hurtling through this puzzle until I got stuck in the lower right corner. I didn‚Äôt know the miracle, the Picts, or the bunny. I had ‚Äúdon‚Äôt move‚Äù instead of LIE STILL and couldn‚Äôt get past the idea that toddlers and (some) directors both create a lot of sh‚Äî. I worked my way through, but that section gave me enough trouble that I can‚Äôt complain about the overall difficulty.

And yes, BRAVA is a real word, and one that should be said more often. Brava, Kate.
43% faster than average.  The spanners came pretty quickly as did most of the fill.  Not considering the appropriateness of the difficulty level, it was fun.

Friday.

Really??

Now I think they're just messing with us.

A nice puzzle;  yes a tad easy for a Friday but I‚Äôm ok with that, especially as it was gin club last night. An interesting foray into Chinese distilled concoctions.
SHOED felt clunky, though I appreciate it‚Äôs not inaccurate, just not a word one would generally use to discuss hoofed animals. 
Celts before SCOTS held me up. Potaytoes potahtoes.

Altogether a pleasant outing that made me smile (FRIEND MATERIAL) but didn‚Äôt make me work too hard. BRAVA.

I came to say that anyone who found that easy is on another planet. 

Then I found that it‚Äôs just me who had to work at it. 

Never mind. 

I found it Friday worthy. It was work and was enjoyable 

Thanks.

What is this spherical object the woman is holding? She's looking at it as if she has no idea what it is or what to do with it or how it got in her hand. Was it something sent to her in the DHL express pack? What will happen if she squeezes it?

Seems to be a coffee in the other hand so she might have had a recent encounter with a BARISTA but that doesn't explain anything.
This was more like a Tuesday or even Monday puzzle. What's up?
A Friday without Wordplay help is a good Friday. Thanks for a fun puzzle, Kate! Have a great day, y‚Äôall!

Days are getting longer! Can't wait for Sweater Weather! Enjoyed the puzzle. üòä And like anything else, the more we do puzzles, the better we get at them and faster we complete them. Plus,  gives me time to work on the other Games.
Answer key has not come up. Error message every day for a week. Please fix this.
One day I‚Äôd like to 34A be clued as [REENIGNE].

Also, no one ever says "aped" except crossword puzzles.

Finished, no music. Flyspecked, found BRAVA. No music. Read column. Already hard those answers. Sighed and did check puzzle. 

An n for the first letter of 59a, instead of an M; I suppose I was thinking of Narnia‚Ä¶ but InPORTS? Palm to forehead. 

And still under a half hour. Nice puzzle. Is there a bear coming tomorrow?
Has there ever been a perfect puzzle where no one complained? I personally find every day is a challenge. I feel victorious when I solve faster than my average.
Any help with WIZEN and BRAVA? I can only compute wisen and bravo.

Brava Kate! Anyone who likes OVENWARE, FINE LINENS, and SWEATER WEATHER is definitely FRIEND MATERIAL! Jane Siberry opines: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yDy1W9X5GDA&list=RDyDy1W9X5GDA&start_radio=1 (dig those 80's dos!)

This was not a puzzle made by someone trying to impress ‚Äì it didn‚Äôt have a ‚ÄúLook at me!‚Äù frantic vibe. No, to me it felt like Kate worked to pepper the puzzle with feel-good answers, that is, this was made by a giver.  

Answers that recall contentment: BARISTAS, SHORE, sourdough loaves, SWEATER WEATHER, FRIEND MATERIAL, FINE LINENS (those last three, BTW, are NYT answer debuts).  Beautiful words like SWAGGER and WIZENS.   

A puzzle AT EASE with itself.

And, well into the winter, contentment ‚Äì coziness ‚Äì felt good to me.  

Also standing out was the quality of the grid-build, a low-count (68), low-black-square count (30) box so cleanly filled.

A couple of serendipities added to the loveliness.  The rhyming abuttees MALIGN and OPINE, and the almost identical STATIN and STAIN.

Starting the day with a splash of beauty and excellence ‚Äì with feel-good ‚Äì well, that‚Äôs a gift.  Thank you, Kate!

Not immediately noticing the question mark in [Gets wise to?], SuSSES seemed perfectly fine but could not figure which gender BRAVu fit.  

On my way to completion I learned that soss is a type of door hinge (plus some other stuff). 

So, a hearty [Well done!] from me.

I‚Äôll tell you what‚Äôs made up in spring: ‚Äúsweater weather‚Äù. Those kids at the bus stop need to befriend more, and warmer, material.


But this sunny puzzle did have some strength.

Puzzles are easier, but the broken timer keeps trying to make the case that they really are hard.

This never happened when Biden was president.

Always glad to see another Katie Hawkins day and wasn't disappointed. Typical tough Friday for me; a lot of pondering and working the crosses and a couple of completely unfamiliar phrases, but managed to get it all together. 

And... a rather remarkable puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

....

In careful typography, of course, the multiplication sign "√ó" (Unicode U+00D7) is slightly different than the lower-case "x" (Unicode U+OO78). But who has time for that?

Similarly, as a musician, I know that there is difference between a flat sign (‚ô≠) and a lower case "b," and a sharp sign (‚ôØ) and the hashtag "#." But, unless I need to mollify some obdurate musicological pedant, I have no problem with "C#" or "Db."
As I finished this puzzle I assumed there were would be complaints about how "easy" it is.  I didn't find it all that easy and, as a result, feel pretty darn good about my efforts this morning.

I took the grinding in the clue for BARISTAS to be a reference to the grinding of the beans, not the grueling hours Sam referred to.

When I finished the puzzle this morning, I predicted to my wife that there would be many complaints regarding the low degree of difficulty.
Everyone has their level, what is easy for some is challenging for others.  I take them as they come, easy or hard, it is the experience that matters.  This was a rare Friday that I did not have to resort to Easy Mode.

For those who don‚Äôt quite get yesterday‚Äôs and today‚Äôs complaints about challenge level, I‚Äôd like to respectfully submit an analogy, please indulge me:
You are an opera aficionado. You have season tickets to the finest opera house in the world, which on weekends routinely provides the best performances with complex themes, bold staging of classics and the newest avante garde masterpieces. During the week they provide lighter, shorter productions for families or those new to opera‚Äîwhich you don‚Äôt mind, it can be a nice diversion and in any case you hope will create an even greater interest and market for something you love.

Gradually, though, you notice the quality of the weekend operas goes down. Maybe they only show more mainstream operas that everyone is familiar with, with oversimplified staging, translated into English, cut so they are not as long, or start spending less on stars or production values. You suspect it‚Äôs because the demand for opera is going down and they are trying to sell more to the general public.
(Continued in next post)
BRAVA on this fine Friday puzzle.  Enjoyable from start to finish.

My fellow crossword solvers, you're all FRIEND MATERIAL.
Including you curmudgeons.

TGIF.

(Continued from last post)
Of course you would expect the critical reviews of those productions to reflect that, and for long-time patrons to complain to the theater. And, to be honest, you die a little bit every time you leave the theater and hear people who are not as passionate about opera as you say ‚ÄúI loved this‚Äîit‚Äôs so fun and easy to understand‚ÄîI‚Äôm so glad they got rid of those stuffy, tedious shows they were putting on.‚Äù You don‚Äôt have anything against those folks‚Äîreal opera isn‚Äôt for everyone‚Äîbut you wonder why your experience needs to be diminished to cater to them. 

Perhaps all this is just inevitable as tastes and culture change. And eventually, I suppose, the old timers will find acceptance in the new state of events or stop buying tickets. But you wish the theatre at least would be up front when they sell subscriptions that they are deliberately changing the level of their productions to appeal to the general public so you can make an informed decision, and admit that they are no longer the most elite and discerning opera house. And you wish that there were another opera house you could go to that maintained the original standards (which so far as I know doesn‚Äôt exist in the crossword world‚Äîor if so please tell me). 
Does that make sense? And I don‚Äôt even really like opera. Not trying to be elitist but to explain the frustrations of many of us.

Morning, all.  
And especially @Ken S

I love how I feel solving crossword puzzles and have been doing them for over 50 years. I started doing them in the daily paper with pencil. As my confidence grew, I did them in ink. Thrilled when they were available online. Whether they are challenging or breezy doesn‚Äôt matter. I‚Äôm always learning something: vocabulary, trivia, slang, people, geography, history. The eureka moment when I encounter a misdirect and eventually come up with the right answer. I am in awe of the talented and witty constructors here.

If they‚Äôre going to give an easy mode, can Friday (and Saturday and Sunday) puzzles at least be hard? 

Or if you have to make the weekend puzzles so easy, give us a hard mode!

I build underwater bridges. Putting my Bachelor of Reverse Engineering(ERB) to good use.

Doesn't a Reverse Engineer sound like a job title in Bizarro World?

(For those unfamiliar with Bizarro World, it originated in Superman comic books, and was introduced to many people in Seinfeld. Bizarro World is a backward, absurd(woohoo) version of Earth. Their planet, Htrae, is cube-shaped, as opposed to flat like ours.

In Bizarro World one might find bridges being built under water, difficult late-week puzzles, and national leaders who are capable, reasonable, and trustworthy.)

I had an odd experience with this puzzle. It took me awhile to find a toehold, and I ended up solving it rather chaotically, bouncing around the grid, and assuming I‚Äôd have to surrender and look up a couple‚Ä¶but I managed to push through and was surprised to see that I finished around a third under my Friday average. I know a number of solvers have complained about it being too easy, and I guess my time (though a bit over the median) does fall within the general sense (that the median solver finished 20 percent under their average) but I nonetheless found it a pleasant challenge and,  with coffee, a nice start to my day.

Zipped through this one, and choose to believe it is due to my improving skills, so please don't insist the puzzles are getting easier. Give me some time to glow with pride, and thank you. 

Definitely some answers I did not know (but I do now!), so I needed the crosses. I think I went through twice, completely, and that did it.

But, it being Friday, it's ER volunteer day for me, so I shall get up, get dressed, and go off to "work." Many of the staff there do all the puzzles as well, so I will happily share that all my puzzles are done, and done well. (Nyah, Nyah) Okay, I'll think it quietly to myself. 

Have a lovely day, FRIEND MATERIALs!

Really enjoyed this! It was fast for a Friday, but I couldn't fill everything in on first read, so it provided a fun dose of satisfaction in having to figure things out while still feeling very smooth overall.

For everyone's information (for what it's worth), in Italian there are four different ways to say "That's great"--

bravo--for one single male person, pronounced brav-oh
brava--for one single female person, pronounced brav-ah
bravi--for more than one male person, pronounced brav-ee
brave--for more than one female person, pronounced brav-ay

for males and females together, also bravi
Example: one male and 800 females--bravi!!

Italian is a great language: once you know a few rules, you can pronounce almost any word in the language.

I'm delighted to see Rhea Seehorn in today's puzzle. Not only that, I'm even willing to let yesterday's Joan Jett appearance dwindle. Bad Reputation...wow, girl!

I didn't see Pluribus, but I can't even imagine her in another role outside of Kim Wexler. Rhea is definitely on my short list of celebrities whom I'd love to buy a beer. Although, I her case, it would have to be shots of Zafiro A√±ejo.

To those who say the puzzles are getting too easy, I understand. But not because I‚Äôm one of you. I started doing NYT crosswords during Covid  and since then I‚Äôve gotten much better, mostly by learning the likely tricks rather than because I got smarter. I can easily see how those of you who have larger funds of knowledge and have more experience are crying for harder puzzles. 

Maybe it is just that the crossword puzzle format itself limits what can be consistently achieved by constructors, and not the NYT or the constructors themselves. Constraints may create an upper limit of difficulty for human puzzle constructors, and if more AI created puzzles appear, I can only imagine the complaints! 

Fortunately for me, @NYT, you are right where I like you to be. But then again I usually crash and burn watching Jeopardy, and usually after the ‚ÄúMonday level cluing‚Äù of the $400 answers.
Any puzzle with a Pluribus reference is a friend of mine. Hope to see a lot more of Seehorn, on screen and crosswords alike.

Thank you, Kate, for such a fun Friday and for your lovely ode to friendship in your constructor notes. I, too, love and value my friendships through our ongoing seasons of SWEATER WEATHER, shopping SPREES and sunny days on the SHORE!

Northeast FRIENDs, a weekend SNOW DAY/night is headed our way -- stay safe & warm! ‚ùÑÔ∏è
We don't have too many snow days around here, but schools close when the roads are icy.  I had roughed in "show dogs" whch didn't work. Maybe the show dogs will turn up in another puzzle.

This wasn't as brutal a puzzle as I feared.  I only needed six of the 'easy mode' clues (thank you, Christina Iverson!)

Have a good weekend, everyone!

The editor of this column is not very creative. This column doesn't provide hints that help you solve the puzzle, it just spoils the best clues without helping with the obscure ones. They should not provide hints to all the longest entries. Those can be solved by getting the cross-clues. This column would be helpful if they gave hints to proper nouns and obscure facts, not long wordplay clues.

Hate to be discouraging to those who are stretching but we should have at least one or two chanllenging days and something to aspire to.

Here‚Äôs an idea, which would require a fair bit of work from the NYT Games software developers, and then ongoing extra work for the puzzle editors in perpetuity, but would potentially split the Solomonic baby right down the middle: supplement the gold star with a silver star.

This is a slightly more detailed version of another suggestion I‚Äôve heard several folks propose recently, which I also love ‚Äî having ‚Äúeasy mode‚Äù clues every day of the week (or at the very least, Thursday-Saturday).

In my vision, the little cheating menu in the apps would include an ‚Äúeasy mode‚Äù option, which would swap in a set of easy-mode clues, and potentially also change the overlay rendering (e.g. making the circles and shaded shading from this Thursday‚Äôs puzzle appear).

After activating easy mode, a solver would no longer be eligible for a gold star; but as long as they didn‚Äôt use any other cheats, they‚Äôd still be eligible for a *silver* star.

And then you‚Äôd have separate gold- and silver-star streaks.

As for hard-copy solvers: the NYT would either have to publish both versions of each puzzle, or go with the gold-star version only (something tells me Barry could live with that).

Hey, a person can dream‚Ä¶

Delightful Friday puzzle, although I do agree with others who‚Äôve said the clues were a bit on the nose for a Friday.

It‚Äôs disappointing and a little frustrating to see ‚Äúshoed‚Äù for 40A. ‚ÄòShod‚Äô is basically crosswordese, and when I first saw the clue I thought, ‚ÄúWell it can‚Äôt be ‚Äòshod‚Äô since it‚Äôs a five-letter word‚Ä¶‚Äù

It was a rather fast puzzle, but I enjoyed it... Found the cluing more direct than expected, but I always appreciate if there are clues that produce a smile or a chuckle, so I did like the clue for SASSES, though I started with SuSSES until I noticed the question mark. 

That little area in the lower left was my only slowdown having shags before AFROS and hoping "Well done" was a reference to steak preferences. I did not know the NYC based dance group without all the crosses. Still, this really zipped by.

BRAVA instead of BRAVO cost me a couple of minutes. So gendered. I'm not necessarily complaining, as it's in the dictionary, but I found it surprising.

The white ball in the picture accompanying today's "Wordplay" column looks to my eye like a cue ball, but I'm sure it's a "stress ball", those silly, squeezy things that are given away at conventions and trade fairs to lure people to manufacturers' tables.

They're fun to hold and squeeze -- for about 10 seconds -- and then they wind up in the trash...and the land-fill.  Has anyone actually used them to relieve stress?

But this got me thinking about other stress-relieving fads that have popped up, become ubiquitous, and then disappeared.  Does anyone remember fidget spinners? Poppers?  How about Silly Bandz?
Where are they all now?
I think it must be associated with the rise of ADHD diagnoses, but I'm not sure if it's the cause or the effect.

The "Miracle" of the MARNE was that the French actually won a battle. Essentially, the Germans were worn out from kicking their butts all over the Low Countries, and von Moltke had over-extended his supply lines. I'm playing extreme Devil's advocate here, but if the French had not held, Paris would have fallen, and the trench warfare and brutal attrition that followed would have been avoided. And WWII would not have happened, or maybe it would have been between Germany and Russia.
I couldn't get PORNSTARS to quite fit for "ones always grinding at their jobs," though it worked well with my early attempts at the crosses.
Terrific fun. Thanks Kate, and thanks Sam for your contribution to our understanding and enjoyment.

Xochitl means flower in Nahuatl (pronounced ‚ÄúNa-watl‚Äù), the language of the AZTECs‚Äù. Now that‚Äôs a word that sure to stick with me! Thanks for the lesson!

commentBody:
@JayTee

But we know there are loads of hard submissions being rejected - just ask @SP. When a Pole is solving Thursdays in Tuesday and Fridays in Wednesday time, something is rotten in the state of Cruciverbia.

@Mishlev 

I was reading the comments about the Thursday puzzle roughly 24 hours ago. It occurred to me that the people with the fastest solving times would be making comments sooner than those who struggle more. Also, those who are more serious about solving the puzzles are likely to start the puzzle earlier. Two hypotheses which, if correct, would cause there to be fewer complaints about the puzzle being too easy as it gets later in the day. I didn't get a chance to check this out but it should be easy to get an idea of the trend using a simple visual method. I'd be inclined to simply make a list of the attitudes of the commentors over time. Something like EENENNDENN, where E is a mention of the puzzle being Easy, D a mention of Difficult, and N indicates the comment was Neutral or made No mention of difficulty.  Regardless, people who comment close together in time are likely to be more alike in ability and opinion of a puzzle than those making comments further apart.

Another thought about the comments was about those who compared recent puzzles to ones published several years ago. There are a few reasons the old puzzles may seem harder including changes in how words are used and commonly known trivia, as well as a learning curve for those who have been solving for a number of years. But there are also good reasons why the Times may be trying to make the puzzle accessible to more people as they rely on puzzles to help maintain profitability.

Just some thoughts.

@Marigold

Try archived puzzles from 2021. They are much more difficult than at present, even though the trivia is still recent. Puzzles from the 90s are a trivia nightmare, of course, but you don't need to go that far back in the archives to see how overall difficulty has decreased.

@JayTee

The NYT receives a great deal more puzzle submissions than they can use.

@Marigold,

Your analysis makes sense. Faster solvers would comment on the puzzle sooner, and those who have solved here for a long time tend to start when the puzzles drop the night before. So early comments by those finishing soonest would tend to skew towards the puzzle being easy.

@NYC Traveler

And one step further:

Newer solvers have no basis for comparison, so they wonder why the oldsters want to spoil a puzzle they were able to solve.  

Newbies aren't supposed to be able to solve Friday and Saturday puzzles without a lot of hard thinking, and perhaps a Google or ten.  You shouldn't expect to start puzzling for the first time ever and be able to solve every one of them.

I remember back to 1980, when I took a puzzle book with me on vacation (weekly progression not established yet; they were just randomly more and less difficult) and wondering why I could solve some all the way through, and not get 1/3 done with others (no Google around then, either).

It's just the way it is.  If a newer solver can solve these late-week puzzles easily after a year or two, they will be maxed out in two or three more years, and move onto something more challenging, like golf.
When I started doing these puzzles in 2023, my first Saturday took me 4 hours - with lookups.

Shoe -- sing. noun, ALSO trans. vb. present tense
Shoes -- pl. noun, ALSO trans. vb. present tense

Shod -- trans. vb., past partic. (The farrier had shod the horse.)
